segments.text: What's he going to say? Maybe we ought to talk to him before he sees it.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: He saw it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What-how did he see it? I mean, I was the first one up. He was still in bed.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: He was out there when it happened.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: When?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Um, about four this morning. Uh- I heard a crack and I looked out and I saw him standing there.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What was he doing out at four in the morning?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know. But after it cracked he went back in the house and he cried in the kitchen.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Did you talk to him?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, I uh-, I figured the best thing to do was to leave him alone.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: He cried hard, huh?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I could hear it right through the floor.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What was he doing out there at that time? He was dreaming about him again. He's walking around at night again.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I guess he is.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Could he-he's acting just like he did after he died, you know?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What's the meaning in that?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: But I know one thing, mom. We've made a terrible mistake with dad.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, what do you mean? What?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Being dishonest with him. That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you mean, dishonest?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know Larry's not coming back and I know that too. Why do we go on letting him think that we believe with him?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What, you're going to argue with him?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, I don't want to argue with him, but it's time that he realized that no one believes that Larry's coming back anymore.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You can't tell him that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We got to tell him that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: We can't. It just won't work.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know, for God's sakes it's been three years. No one comes back after three years. It's insane.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: They do come back.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know, but he doesn't know that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Three years has been a long time.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All right. Just- Sit down, mom. I want to talk to you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It's those Goddamn newspapers, you know? I mean, it's like every day they come out with this new person that comes along. And the next one's going to be Larry.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All right. All right. Just come on, sit down.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know-you know why I asked Annie here, right?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Why?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, I have an idea, but go on, tell me, what's the story?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I want to ask her to marry me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Come on, you know that's not only my business.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, it is. I mean, what do you want me to do? You're grown up; you know what's going on in your mind.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So it's all right. I'll just go ahead with it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, you better make sure your father's not- No- I'm just saying.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: See, then it's not just my business. God, you have
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: -Oh, you infuriate me sometimes. You know, it's not just my business too if dad throws a fit.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: God. You have such a talent for ignoring things.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah, well I ignore what I got to ignore.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: And she-she's Larry's girl.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, she is not Larry's girl.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, from your father's point of view she is. I mean, he's still alive. You've got no right to take her.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: If you go on from that point, I don't know where you go.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: 'Cause listen, I'm telling you, I don't know where to go from there. Do you?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, I don't know.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you want from me?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because other people will suffer. My whole entire life, time and time after time.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You're a considerate fella and there's nothing wrong in that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: To hell with that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: There's nothing wrong with it.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I didn't ask Annie yet.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You didn't ask her yet?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I wanted to get this settled first.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you? I mean, what if she feels the same way as your father?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well then I guess it's over then. But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'll find out. But then after it's all over we'll thrash it out with dad, right?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Mom, don't avoid me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You know, the trouble is you've never had enough women. No, you never did.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So what? I'm not fast with women.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't understand why it has to be her.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Because it is.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I just-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean, you haven't seen her since the war. I mean, it's been five years.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It just is. I-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I grew up with her. Okay. All these years, when I think of someone I want to be my wife I think of Annie. What do you want, a diagram?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: No, I don't want a diagram.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: He thinks he's coming back. You go-go on and marry her, I mean, you're pronouncing her dead. And what's going to happen to your father, huh? I don't know. Do you?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Okay. All right, then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Just, listen. Give it more thought, is all.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, I've given it three years of thought.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: But if I can't have that here then I'll get out.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What the hell is this?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I'll get out. I'll marry her somewhere else. Maybe New York.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You're crazy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I've been a sucker too long. I'm through with it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You're what-you're going to leave the business? But you can't do that. What the hell is this?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The business. The business doesn't inspire me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes. I like it an hour out of the day. If I have to grub for money all day long at least that evening I want it beautiful. I want a wife. I want a family. I want some kids. I want to build something I can give myself to.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Now, Annie's in the middle of all that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Now, where do I find it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Tell me something.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You'd leave that business.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes. On this I would.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You can't do that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Then help me stay here.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: All right, but you can't do that. You can't talk like that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Okay. Just-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: We've worked all our lives for you. Only for you, Chris. The whole shootin' match is for you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah, I know, I know, just help me stay here, all right?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'm going to.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You just can't talk like that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I am thinking like that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't know you, do I?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah. I can see that.
segments.speaker: F
